awd_titl_txt: Selective Hydrocarbon Production from Carbon Dioxide Electro-reduction via Electrochemical Potential and Mass Transport Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
The use of renewable electricity to convert water and carbon dioxide into energy-dense fuels and high-valued chemicals can improve the storage and utilization of intermittent solar and wind energy. This technology for "solar fuels" has benefits in utilization of renewable energy sources and in sequestering carbon from carbon dioxide into value added chemicals used to make industrial products such as polymers. This project utilizes an electrochemical conversion with carbon dioxide as a feedstock and an externally applied electrical potential (voltage) to produce higher valued chemicals as a goal. The researchers will investigate how to engineer the application of the electrochemical potential to the device in order to improve the yield of products such as ethylene in an energy efficient manner. The project will involve investigations of the impact of using a series of pulses of electrical potential rather than a steady application on the elementary reactions that occur at the boundary of the electrode and electrolyte of the device. The goal is that application of a series of voltage pulses and varying its frequency and energy magnitude could tune the reactions occurring to favor production of hydrocarbons over competing products such as carbon monoxide. For educational broader impacts, the PIs will continue their commitment to fostering undergraduate researchers through summer and academic year research projects. The PIs will continue to sponsor a research ethics workshop for researchers in energy and materials designed for both students and senior investigators. The research outcomes will be integrated into Cornell chemical engineering capstone course projects that are designed to integrate technological innovation, intellectual property, practical engineering, entrepreneurship, and communication in carbon dioxide processing technologies. These activities are aimed at improving students' interests in chemical and materials engineering at both undergraduate and graduate levels, especially for women and members of underrepresented minorities to build diversity in the future STEM workforce.

This research will result in fundamental understanding on how to control the selectivity of the carbon dioxide electroreduction reaction by tailoring the temporal profile of the applied electrochemical potential. A number of variables including surface adsorbates, electrical double layer, and transport, play an important role in the carbon dioxide electroreduction selectivity. The project's driving hypothesis is that key reaction and transport phenomena in this system occur at varying timescales that could be taken advantage of to impact the observed reaction selectivity. This project seeks to control these variables by tuning the temporal profile of the electrochemical potential pulse. The central focus is to identify the principles for designing the temporal profile of the electrochemical potential to promote hydrocarbon production and suppress the hydrogen evolution reaction. In addition to selectivity control, the temporal control of the electrochemical potential represents an opportunity to address open questions concerning competing pathways in the carbon dioxide electroreduction and their rate constants. Spectroscopy and simulations will be done in parallel to reveal the thermodynamics and kinetics during the temporal control of the electrochemical potential.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Catalysis is crucial in driving innovation and progress within the chemical industry. Approximately 80-90% of chemical processes rely on catalysts to accelerate reactions and improve efficiency, leading to a wide range of applications, from producing valuable chemicals to environmental control through catalytic converters. Heterogeneous catalysis, in particular, goes beyond laboratories and factories, significantly contributing to the global economy. With an estimated annual sales figure of around $1.5 trillion, heterogeneous catalysis generates substantial revenue across various industries, promoting economic growth and job opportunities worldwide. 

Electrocatalytic processes have emerged as promising solutions to address pressing environmental challenges. Alongside well-established technologies like fuel cells and hydrogen electrolyzers, electrochemical processes to transform CO2 from an environmental liability into a valuable resource for chemical products are gaining prominence as scalable and economical solutions to mitigate anthropogenic CO2 emissions' impact on global climate change. However, realizing the potential of electrochemical CO2 reduction requires overcoming several technological challenges. One such challenge involves creating a catalytic environment conducive to forming valuable hydrocarbons, particularly high-value products like ethylene. Copper electrocatalysts have shown unique abilities to facilitate the necessary C-C coupling to form C2 products. Nevertheless, achieving selectivity for specific high-value products rather than a broad mixture, poses additional challenges, impacting downstream separation costs. In electrochemical CO2 reduction, up to 16 different hydrocarbons have been reported, making chemical selectivity a critical consideration. To address this, scientists and engineers have extensively studied the role of the electrode, electrolyte, and electrolyzer design. In a departure from the mainstream focus on static variables, we hypothesized that dynamic variables, such as pulsing the applied potential with on/off cycles at specific frequencies, could serve as an unexplored "knob" to modulate the catalytic environment near the catalyst surface.

The primary goal of our project was to gain a comprehensive understanding of the scientific principles governing transport and reaction processes in pulsed electrochemical CO2 reduction. We aimed to apply this knowledge to establish design principles that optimize the electrochemical selectivity for high-value C2 products. We combined electrochemical measurements with spectroscopy and simulations to investigate the thermodynamics and kinetics during the temporal control of the electrochemical potential. Below, we summarize the scientific advances made in this project. 

In-situ X-ray adsorption spectroscopy allowed us to identify and monitor changes in the bulk Cu valence state, which remained reduced during pulsing, while surface hydroxides were adsorbed during the anodic pulsed potential. This pulsed mechanism favored CO2 reduction and increased stability due to two effects: a) proton desorption/displacement by hydroxides during the anodic potential, suppressing H2 production, and b) the accumulation of adsorbed hydroxides, promoting CO adsorption and preventing Cu deactivation. 

The composition and concentration of the electrolyte are known to impact product selectivity, but their dynamic processes and effects at the solid/electrolyte interface during pulse-modulated electrolysis were poorly understood. We investigated how the electrolyte composition (KCl and KHCO3) and concentration impacted hydrocarbon formation and the competing evolution of hydrogen gas. These results provide new mechanistic insights into the pulsed electrochemical CO2 reduction mechanism, particularly regarding proton-donator ability and ionic conductivity.

We systematically examined the effects of pulse potential, duration, and profile symmetry on the resulting products from electrocatalytic CO2 reduction. This study offered new physical insight into the role of co-adsorbed ions, interfacial charge, and changing electric field at the reaction interface on C-C coupling. We demonstrated that symmetric pulse shapes optimize C2 selectivity, attributed to a balance of microkinetic steps and optimization of the local reaction environment for C-C coupling through electrolyte ion co-adsorption and electric field effects.

We showed that the transient response of the electrochemical system can offer critical insights into the reaction mechanisms. Our analysis using time-resolved current in response to a step-change in voltage (chronoamperometry) revealed that the electrochemical CO2 reduction involves a chemical reaction interposed between two charge transfer reactions (known as the "ECE" mechanism). This finding contradicts previous postulations of a concerted (proton-coupled electron transport) pathway for hydrogenation to form *COOH-. Instead, it involves sequential electron and proton transfers.

The project's impact extends beyond creating new scientific knowledge and has the potential to lead to the development of new electrolyzer technologies for transforming CO2 into value-added chemical products. Graduate students supported through this grant received extensive training and experience in analyzing electrochemical processes, bridging experimental and computational approaches. The project also incorporated outreach and education, integrating scientific advances from electrochemical studies into sustainable energy courses. Additionally, a workshop focused on research conduct, from proposal writing and review to day-to-day activities in the lab and fostering a productive research environment.


Last Modified: 09/28/2023
Modified by: Tobias Hanrath

Image

    Tobias Hanrath

    Mechanistic insights into electrochemical CO2 reduction from chronoamperometric measurements
